item.title: Super-resolution imaging of limited-size objects
item.author: Taeyong ChangGiorgio AdamoNikolay I. Zheludev
item.content:encoded:
Limited-size object microscopy (LSOM) enables label-free super-resolution imaging of isolated nano-objects with a resolution as low as λ/8 under the sole assumption of the limited size of the imaged object.

Taeyong ChangGiorgio AdamoNikolay I. Zheludev

Nature Photonics

item.title: Quantum metrology for human health
item.author: Alex R. JonesIan S. GilmorePeter L. Knight
item.content:encoded:
Quantum technologies could be transformative for healthcare. Alex Jones, Ian Gilmore and Peter Knight discuss the role of metrology in the adoption of these technologies.

Alex R. JonesIan S. GilmorePeter L. Knight

Nature Physics

item.title: Efficient integrated quantum memory for light
item.author: Ruo-Ran MengPei-Xi LiuGuang-Can Guo
item.content:encoded:
Integrated quantum memories based on 151Eu3+:Y2SiO5 crystals coupled with impedance-matched optical cavities are demonstrated. Multiplexed quantum storage efficiencies of 80.3% and 69.8% are achieved for weak coherent pulses and telecom-heralded single photons, respectively.

Ruo-Ran MengPei-Xi LiuGuang-Can Guo

Nature Photonics

item.title: Large-scale quantum communication networks with integrated photonics
item.author: Yun ZhengHanyu WangJianwei Wang
item.content:encoded:
A lab-scale proof-of-principle demonstration of a quantum network comprising one server chip and 20 client photonic chips implementing twin-field quantum key distribution shows excellent scalability and reliability and yields a pathway towards future large-scale networks.

Yun ZhengHanyu WangJianwei Wang

Nature

item.title: Parity-doublet coherence times in optically trapped polyatomic molecules
item.author: Paige RobichaudChristian HallasJohn M. Doyle
item.content:encoded:
Optically trapped CaOH molecules in parity-doublet states achieve coherence times exceeding vibrational lifetimes, which are a defining milestone for the use of polyatomic molecules in quantum science.

Paige RobichaudChristian HallasJohn M. Doyle

Nature

item.title: Continuous-wave narrow-linewidth vacuum ultraviolet laser source
item.author: Qi XiaoGleb PenyazkovShiqian Ding
item.content:encoded:
A continuous-wave narrow-linewidth vacuum ultraviolet laser generated using four-wave mixing in cadmium vapour is shown to improve linewidth by five orders of magnitude compared with previous single-frequency lasers below 190 nm.

Qi XiaoGleb PenyazkovShiqian Ding

Nature

item.title: Single-shot parity readout of a minimal Kitaev chain
item.author: Nick van LooFrancesco ZatelliLeo P. Kouwenhoven
item.content:encoded:
A measurement strategy is described that is able to read out the parity of minimal two-site Kitaev chains in real time, by coupling two Majoranas and resolving their quantum capacitance.

Nick van LooFrancesco ZatelliLeo P. Kouwenhoven

Nature

item.title: Charge-neutral electrons are odd — except when they’re even
item.author: Andrew P. Higginbotham
item.content:encoded:
Electrons can seem electrically neutral in some devices. Neutral states can be distinguished in real time by a measure of their electron pairing called odd or even parity.

Andrew P. Higginbotham

Nature

item.title: Sub-part-per-trillion test of the Standard Model with atomic hydrogen
item.author: Lothar MaisenbacherVitaly WirthlThomas Udem
item.content:encoded:
Measurement of the 2S–6P transition in cryogenic atomic hydrogen using laser spectroscopy reveals a proton radius value that is 2.5-fold more precise than previous determinations and in excellent agreement with the muonic value, and tests the Standard Model to 0.7 parts per trillion.

Lothar MaisenbacherVitaly WirthlThomas Udem

Nature

item.title: Heralded high-dimensional photon–photon quantum gate
item.author: Zhi-Feng LiuZhi-Cheng RenHui-Tian Wang
item.content:encoded:
A general protocol for high-dimensional entangling gates is developed and applied for two four-dimensional qudits encoded in orbital angular momentum (OAM). The phase-locking technique stabilizes OAM sorters, leading to a process fidelity within a range from 0.71 to 0.85.

Zhi-Feng LiuZhi-Cheng RenHui-Tian Wang

Nature Photonics

item.title: Non-equilibrium entropy production and information dissipation in a non-Markovian quantum dot
item.author: Yuejun ShenChutian ChenAaron M. Lindenberg
item.content:encoded:
Experimentally assessing entropy production in nanosystems is challenging. Now, the dissipation is visualized in a time-dependently driven non-Markovian quantum-dot blinking process in real time.

Yuejun ShenChutian ChenAaron M. Lindenberg

Nature Physics

item.title: Super-broadband stimulated Raman scattering spectroscopy and imaging
item.author: Jin GuoMingzhen WangHanqing Xiong
item.content:encoded:
A stimulated Raman scattering method based on dual-band laser-induced quantum interference enables ultra broadband and rapid hyperspectral Raman imaging of biological tissue and the detection of up to 11 key biomarkers in human serum.

Jin GuoMingzhen WangHanqing Xiong

Nature Photonics

item.title: Scaling quantum photonics networks
item.author: Yun-Ru FanQiang Zhou
item.content:encoded:
Mode mixing and mapping with a piece of multimode optical fibre and spatial light modulators creates a bridge between two isolated quantum networks, linking distant nodes with quantum connectivity.

Yun-Ru FanQiang Zhou

Nature Photonics

item.title: Quantum computers will finally be useful: what’s behind the revolution
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
A string of surprising advances suggests usable quantum computers could be here in a decade.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: Classically impossible cryptography
item.author: Prabhanjan Ananth
item.content:encoded:
Quantum states cannot be copied, which could enable encryption schemes that are impossible classically. Now, substantial progress has been made towards a practical uncloneable encryption protocol using ideas from quantum information theory.

Prabhanjan Ananth

Nature Physics

item.title: Large-scale analogue quantum simulation using atom dot arrays
item.author: M. B. DonnellyY. ChungM. Y. Simmons
item.content:encoded:
A new platform comprising large-scale 2D arrays of quantum dots patterned with sub-nanometre precision, with each quantum dot defined by tens of phosphorus atoms doped into silicon, allows for analogue simulation of quantum materials on arbitrary lattices.

M. B. DonnellyY. ChungM. Y. Simmons

Nature

item.title: Uncloneable encryption from decoupling
item.author: Archishna BhattacharyyaEric Culf
item.content:encoded:
Quantum correlations enable some cryptographic protocols that are classically impossible. Now the security of an uncloneable encryption scheme using quantum systems has been proven.

Archishna BhattacharyyaEric Culf

Nature Physics

item.title: Measuring spin correlation between quarks during QCD confinement
item.author: B. E. AboonaJ. AdamM. Zyzak
item.content:encoded:
The STAR experiment at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory demonstrates evidence of spin correlations in \(\Lambda \bar{\Lambda }\) hyperon pairs inherited from virtual spin-correlated strange quark–antiquark pairs during QCD confinement.

B. E. AboonaJ. AdamM. Zyzak

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: More than one-third of cancer cases are preventable
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Nearly 40% of new cancer cases worldwide are linked to things we can change, such as smoking. Plus, the NIH is rolling back red tape on some types of human research and the unexpected success of ice skates.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Particle collisions cast light on how matter forms from seemingly empty space
item.author: Yasmine Amhis
item.content:encoded:
Fundamental particles called quarks can be created in quantum-correlated pairs. These correlations can be passed on to larger particles that form from the quarks.

Yasmine Amhis

Nature

item.title: Signatures of fractional charges via anyon–trions in twisted MoTe2
item.author: Weijie LiChristiano Wang BeachXiaodong Xu
item.content:encoded:
Fractionally charged excitations at zero magnetic field in twisted MoTe2 bilayers, a recently discovered fractional quantum anomalous Hall system, are observed via anyon-trions, excitonic complexes formed by binding a trion to a fractional charge.

Weijie LiChristiano Wang BeachXiaodong Xu

Nature

item.title: Resolving intervalley gaps and many-body resonances in moiré superconductors
item.author: Hyunjin KimGautam RaiStevan Nadj-Perge
item.content:encoded:
This study of magic-angle twisted trilayer graphene moiré superconductors using scanning tunnelling microscopy and spectroscopy identifies two energy gaps that develop from many-body resonance in this highly tunable class of materials.

Hyunjin KimGautam RaiStevan Nadj-Perge

Nature

item.title: Universal loss and gain characterization inside photonic integrated circuits
item.author: Haoran ChenRuxuan LiuXu Yi
item.content:encoded:
A universal, non-destructive and scalable method to precisely characterize loss and gain of optical components inside photonic integrated circuits is discussed.

Haoran ChenRuxuan LiuXu Yi

Nature Photonics

item.title: Mitigated chaos
item.author: Bruno Bertini
item.content:encoded:
Using classical operations to reverse the effects of noise, current quantum devices can outperform classical computers in simulating the dynamics of a chaotic quantum system.

Bruno Bertini

Nature Physics

item.title: Long-lived remote ion-ion entanglement for scalable quantum repeaters
item.author: Wen-Zhao LiuYa-Bin ZhouJian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
Wen-Zhao LiuYa-Bin ZhouJian-Wei Pan

Nature

item.title: Quantum computing isn’t just about scaling
item.author: Murphy Yuezhen Niu
item.content:encoded:
The race to demonstrate quantum error correction often focuses on making ever-larger devices. A demonstration showing that splitting a surface-code logical qubit into two simpler repetition codes substantially reduces logical gate errors reminds us that advancing quantum computing does not hinge solely on scaling qubit numbers.

Murphy Yuezhen Niu

Nature Physics

item.title: Lattice surgery realized on two distance-three repetition codes with superconducting qubits
item.author: Ilya BesedinMichael KerschbaumAndreas Wallraff
item.content:encoded:
Quantum error correction codes protect quantum information, but running algorithms also requires the ability to perform gates on logical qubits. A lattice surgery scheme for fault-tolerant gates has now been demonstrated in a quantum repetition code.

Ilya BesedinMichael KerschbaumAndreas Wallraff

Nature Physics

item.title: China is betting on ‘optical’ computer chips — will they power AI?
item.author: Mohana Basu
item.content:encoded:
Semiconductor chips that process light rather than electricity could boost processing speeds and reduce energy use.

Mohana Basu

Nature

item.title: A cavity-array microscope for parallel single-atom interfacing
item.author: Adam L. ShawAnna SoperJonathan Simon
item.content:encoded:
A cavity-array microscope is realized using intra-cavity lenses to create a two-dimensional array of over 40 modes, each coupled to a single atom in free-space.

Adam L. ShawAnna SoperJonathan Simon

Nature

item.title: Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet
item.author: Xiangbin CaiHaiyang PanWeibo Gao
item.content:encoded:
Optical switching of a moiré Chern ferromagnet is demonstrated in twisted molybdenum ditelluride bilayers using continuous-wave circularly polarized light, paving the way for dissipationless spintronics and quantized Chern junction devices.

Xiangbin CaiHaiyang PanWeibo Gao

Nature

item.title: Low-power integrated optical amplification through second-harmonic resonance
item.author: Devin J. DeanTaewon ParkAmir H. Safavi-Naeini
item.content:encoded:
An integrated optical parametric amplifier on thin-film lithium niobate achieves more than 17 dB gain with less than 200 mW input power.

Devin J. DeanTaewon ParkAmir H. Safavi-Naeini

Nature

item.title: Optical control of integer and fractional Chern insulators
item.author: William HoltzmannWeijie LiXiaodong Xu
item.content:encoded:
Optical control of integer and fractional Chern insulators is demonstrated by circularly polarized optical pumping in tMoTe2.

William HoltzmannWeijie LiXiaodong Xu

Nature

item.title: Prethermalization by random multipolar driving on a 78-qubit processor
item.author: Zheng-He LiuYu LiuHeng Fan
item.content:encoded:
The existence of a long-lived, prethermal regime in many-body systems with tunable heating rates, driven by structured random protocols, is observed using a 78-qubit superconducting quantum processor.

Zheng-He LiuYu LiuHeng Fan

Nature

item.title: Intestinal macrophages modulate synucleinopathy along the gut–brain axis
item.author: Sebastiaan De SchepperViktoras KonstantellosTim Bartels
item.content:encoded:
Muscularis macrophages, housekeepers of enteric nervous system integrity and intestinal homeostasis, modulate α-synuclein pathology and neurodegeneration in models of Parkinson’s disease, and understanding the accompanying mechanisms could pave the way for early-stage biomarkers.

Sebastiaan De SchepperViktoras KonstantellosTim Bartels

Nature

item.title: Optical control over topological Chern number in moiré materials
item.author: O. HuberK. KuhlbrodtT. Smoleński
item.content:encoded:
Optical spin orientation of itinerant ferromagnets in twisted MoTe2 homobilayers is demonstrated, enabling control of topological Chern numbers with circularly polarized light.

O. HuberK. KuhlbrodtT. Smoleński

Nature

item.title: Ferromagnet-like binary switching of a Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnet
item.author: Zhanshan WangYining XiangShiwei Wu
item.content:encoded:
CrPS4, a 2D van der Waals A-type antiferromagnet, is shown to exhibit ideal characteristics of Stoner–Wohlfarth antiferromagnets, such as ferromagnet-like binary switching rather than layer-by-layer flipping as in other 2D A-type antiferromagnets.

Zhanshan WangYining XiangShiwei Wu

Nature

item.title: Demonstration of low-overhead quantum error correction codes
item.author: Ke WangZhide LuDong-Ling Deng
item.content:encoded:
Quantum low-density parity-check error correction codes are anticipated to deliver high performance, but require long-range qubit–qubit interactions. Two of these error correction codes have now been successfully implemented on a superconducting device.

Ke WangZhide LuDong-Ling Deng

Nature Physics

item.title: From quantum computing to mRNA therapeutics: seven technologies to watch in 2026
item.author: Michael Eisenstein
item.content:encoded:
Nature’s round-up of innovations that are poised to make a splash in the year ahead.

Michael Eisenstein

Nature

item.title: Probing quantum mechanics with nanoparticle matter-wave interferometry
item.author: Sebastian PedalinoBruno E. Ramírez-GalindoStefan Gerlich
item.content:encoded:
Quantum interference of sodium nanoparticles, which can each contain more than 7,000 atoms at masses greater than 170,000 Da, is demonstrated.

Sebastian PedalinoBruno E. Ramírez-GalindoStefan Gerlich

Nature

item.title: Schrödinger’s cat just got bigger: quantum physicists create largest ever ‘superposition’
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
Record-breaking experiment shows that a cluster of thousands of atoms can act like a wave as well as a particle.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: Quantum spin resonance in engineered proteins for multimodal sensing
item.author: Gabriel AbrahamsAna ŠtuhecHarrison Steel
item.content:encoded:
A recently developed class of magneto-sensitive fluorescent proteins are engineered to alter the properties of their response to magnetic fields and radio frequencies, enabling multimodal sensing of biological systems.

Gabriel AbrahamsAna ŠtuhecHarrison Steel

Nature

item.title: AI and nuclear energy feature strongly in agenda-setting technologies for 2026
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
Nature’s annual list of technologies to watch is a chance to celebrate progress and stimulate research into both opportunities and risks.

Nature

item.author: Nick Petrić HoweBenjamin Thompson
item.content:encoded:
Quantum superposition gets supersized — plus, US science after a year of Trump.

Nick Petrić HoweBenjamin Thompson

Nature

item.title: Quantum effect observed for biggest objects yet
item.author: Tim Kovachy
item.content:encoded:
An experiment has broken the size record for an object exhibiting matter-wave interference — fuelling the debate about possible size constraints.

Tim Kovachy

Nature

item.title: Symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism
item.author: Tomas JungwirthJairo SinovaLibor Šmejkal
item.content:encoded:
The symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism are reviewed, and compared with traditional ferromagnetism and Néel antiferromagnetism, and magnetic phases with symmetry-protected compensated non-collinear spin orders.

Tomas JungwirthJairo SinovaLibor Šmejkal

Nature

item.title: Dynamical simulations of many-body quantum chaos on a quantum computer
item.author: Laurin E. FischerMatea LeahySergey N. Filippov
item.content:encoded:
Studying many-body quantum chaos on current quantum hardware is hindered by noise and limited scalability. Now it is shown that a superconducting processor, combined with error mitigation, can accurately simulate dual-unitary circuit dynamics.

Laurin E. FischerMatea LeahySergey N. Filippov

Nature Physics

item.title: Publisher Correction: A fault-tolerant neutral-atom architecture for universal quantum computation
item.author: Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: Trapping of single atoms in metasurface optical tweezer arrays
item.author: Aaron HolmanYuan XuSebastian Will
item.content:encoded:
Single strontium atoms are trapped in optical tweezer arrays generated via holographic metasurfaces, overcoming a critical barrier to realizing scalable neutral-atom quantum technologies.

Aaron HolmanYuan XuSebastian Will

Nature

item.title: Emergent topological semimetal from quantum criticality
item.author: D. M. KirschbaumL. ChenS. Paschen
item.content:encoded:
Examples of materials with non-trivial band topology in the presence of strong electron correlations are rare. Now it is shown that quantum fluctuations near a quantum phase transition can promote topological phases in a heavy-fermion compound.

D. M. KirschbaumL. ChenS. Paschen

Nature Physics

item.title: An electrically injected solid-state surface acoustic wave phonon laser
item.author: Alexander WendtMatthew J. StoreyMatt Eichenfield
item.content:encoded:
A completely solid-state, single-chip, microwave-frequency surface acoustic wave phonon laser can generate coherent phonons from thermal noise or resonantly amplify injected phonons using only a direct current bias field.

Alexander WendtMatthew J. StoreyMatt Eichenfield

Nature
